children.subject:
I believe everyone can study abroad, but I also respect that the cost and time might not be right for you.

If you can't study abroad(please try) during school, you have options:

1. Study abroad with a community college. Just enroll, anyone can do it. You can do it now, when you're 50, 60, 70, 100, etc. This works because anyone can enroll in community college.

2. During a summer freshman/sophomore/junior year, go take a 2-3 month trip and stay in hostels/airbnbs. I don't like hostels, but some people do.

3. After graduation, go travel in the summer.

4. During winter breaks, travel for the month.

If you plan on "studying abroad" without the formal program, I have a few suggestions:

a. There is something magical about living in the same place for 2-3 months, and that's the only reason why I think study abroad is a good idea. If you want to see the world, go travel to many cities in a short amount of time. If you want to live and breathe a different culture and have a place in Europe, Asia, Africa, Australia etc be a new home to you, stay in an airbnb/hostel for 1 month at least. The issue is that this can get lonely if you're not put into some kind of forced socialized environment, which is why study abroad formal programs are nice.

b. If you plan on visiting a ton of cities, spend at least 3 days, and 5 is better. Cost goes up, you'll see less cities, but you'll experience each one more. I personally like walking around aimlessly and getting lost until I develop the entire map of the centralized parts within a city in my head. This means I can visualize how to get anywhere within a city from each turn.

c. I'm very content with traveling alone, but it's not for everyone. People get lonely, scared, and bored. In addition, some people, like myself, don't like traveling with people. I suggest traveling to a local city on your own for a week, and going to another local city with friends, and seeing which you prefer. Then you can plan your 2-3 month trip.

d. Life is a long game. You don't have to see the world by the time you graduate. You don't even have to see the world. Just take it step by step, and visualize where you want to go and try to make it happen without losing other aspects of your life(job, savings, etc).

It's very similar to a career fair in that all the different programs/orgs have tables and you can visit the ones you are interested in. It it typically much less crowded than career fairs. The time you spend there entirely depends on how many conversations you want to have and how long you want each of them to be.
Thank you!

Has anyone ever gone to a study abroad fair? How does that work/how is it set up? The flyer says 11-4 but I've never been to one and I'm trying to figure out how much time is typically spent there so I can figure out my schedule.

You're right, it's definitely harder for an L&S transfer student to do this. I would suggest meeting with an Advisor at L&S to see how you might make it work. The summer abroad program, or an independent program after you max out your UC Berkeley units, might be better options.

I think it is not very realistic for the transfer CS students to study abroad. They have too many core courses needed to finish with 4-5 semesters. Is the semester abroad also count for the 5th semester?
Is this on Friday, October 11th or Thursday, October 10th?
This was posted one year ago, so this is outdated.
There is a study abroad in engineering panel happening on October 11th with dinner provided, RSVP here!
Please read my post, open the links, and view the instructions
I am applying to study abroad at the National University of Singapore in the spring (CS major). Who do I have to talk to about possibly getting credit there for upper-division CS courses?
The college modifies the Senior Residency requirement for students studying abroad to make it possible. If you're interested, you should meet with an L&S Adviser to discuss.

https://ls.berkeley.edu/advising/degree-requirements

Under the Senior Residence Requirement / L&S Upper Div Residence Requirement, does this mean that we cannot study abroad the summer after our senior year?
Please click the link to our website. It answers this question.
For the CS minor, would these courses count?
Please click the link to our website. It clearly answers this question.
Are there any pre-approved CS courses for Oxford and Cambridge? How does the CS credit + study abroad work for institutions not in the pre-approved course list?

You could pick two of the "2 units of CS ___" courses and together they would be equivalent to one of your upper division requirements. Or you could use them towards the 7 units of tech elective. Or find new classes for us to review that you think are fully equivalent :)
So most of the pre-approved classes are like 2 units of CS ___. What does that mean? Would we have to come back and take the class at Berkeley, or does it not count as a full class?
Because the CS minor does not have a technical elective requirement, the technical elective courses will not suffice. You must take one equivalent to an actual CS class at Cal

For the CS minor, it states on the application that "Students may transfer up to one CS/EECS upper-division course from study abroad or from another institution (up to 4 units); this must be pre-approved by exception." Does this mean that the pre-approved classes listed above in the Excel sheet that have "Tech Elective/CoE units" equivalency can go towards the minor, or must it be equivalent to an actual CS class at Cal? 

Thanks in advance!

We will have another info session on 4/9 and the Study Abroad Office has Peer Advisers who can offer a student perspective. Unfortunately, I can 't release student contact info. 

Please add your last name to your Piazza account. we can't have annonymous users on EECS 101. 

Best wishes,

Nicole

For those who couldn't make it to the event, is there any way we can still get some info or insight? Possibly connect with someone who spoke at the event?

Thanks for the help!
Please direct questions about study abroad programs and deadlines to the study abroad office.
I'm guessing the deadlines for summer have passed, but what are the deadlines for next fall and spring?
Are there any programs that are still open for the summer?

history.content:
The advising team would like to encourage all CS majors/minor and EECS majors/minors to consider studying abroad during their Cal career. Did you know that the EECS Department has an info page and list of pre-approved courses for students interested in studying abroad? If you're interested in a country/school/course that isn't listed, we can absolutely review it to see if it might fulfill a major requirement. 

Don't want to take a Fall or Spring semester away from campus? The Berkeley Study Abroad office offers summer abroad courses and a global internship program, in which you can get units and work experience in one of thirteen different countries. 

Fun facts

  • Financial aid covers study abroad through UC programs.
  • For international and out of state students, independent programs may be cheaper than studying at Cal. 
  • Completing a study abroad program automatically fulfills L&S students' international studies breadth requirement. 
  • UC Berkeley students win more Gilman Scholarships (up to $5,000) to study abroad than any other institution. Spring and summer applications are open now.
  • Many programs don't require you to know the native language

Study abroad will help students:

  • Develop skills that are critical to a science education
  • Take advantage of unique academic and experiential opportunities in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
  • Participate in a different educational system and get a comparative perspective on the study of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
  • Increase language proficiency
  • Improve critical thinking skills
  • Experience another culture firsthand
  • Develop self-confidence and independence
  • Enhance resumes and/or applications for graduate school
  • Prepare for a career in an internationally competitive world

"People often ask 'Why would you leave the best EE/CS university in the world to study abroad at a university likely teaching your subject at a lower caliber?' But you don't study abroad to learn CS. You already have three or four years (or more, if graduate school is in the cards) to do just that. You study abroad to gain perspective, to ask yourself 'where do I fit in in this world?' To learn other lifestyles. To learn a new language. To develop an identity outside of the academic one that you've known for the last decade of your life. To develop into your own independent person apart from things and people you've known."  - Yuan Yuan, CS B.A. 2017. Studied abroad in Chile.

Study Abroad Fair & Workshops Series

  • Study Abroad Fair: September 28 @ 11:00 am  |   Pauley Ballroom at MLK Jr. Student Union Flyer
  • Study Abroad 101: Choosing a Program: Thursday, October 25, 5 p.m. | Multicultural Community Center, MLK Student Union
  • Financing Study Abroad: Wednesday, October 10,2 p.m. | 375 Le Conte & Thursday, November 15, 5 p.m. | 375 Le Conte
  • Applying to Study Abroad: Wednesday, November 14, 2 p.m. | 375 Le Conte & Thursday, December 6, 5 p.m. | 375 Le Conte
